title: ethdb: storage pebble uses high io
body: #### System information Geth version: `v1.1.0` db.engine: pebble. fullnode with snapshot CL client & version: prysm v3.2.1 OS & Version: Docker (aws kubernetes) aws instance: r5.xlarge(4c-32GiB) Exclusive use of this machine. Disk type: gp2 800GiB geth args: ``` exec geth --authrpc.jwtsecret=/secret/jwtsecret --authrpc.addr=0.0.0.0 --authrpc.port=8551 --authrpc.vhosts=* --http --http.addr=0.0.0.0 --http.port=8599 --http.corsdomain= --http.vhosts=* --http.api=web3,eth,net,engine --nat=extip:$(POD_IP) --port=30303 --ws --ws.addr=0.0.0.0 --ws.port=8546 --ws.origins=* --ws.api=web3,eth,net,engine --datadir=/data/ethereum --ethash.dagdir=/data/ethereum/.ethash --ipcdisable --mainnet "--syncmode=snap" "--cache=12288" "--db.engine=pebble" "--metrics" "--pprof" "--pprof.addr=0.0.0.0" "--pprof.port=6060" ``` #### Scenario At the beginning, the synchronization speed is fast. When it is about to synchronize. Now it's stuck in 0xfe0600(5min). Slow sync speed, too much difference from previous v.1.10.26 ``` {"jsonrpc":"2.0","id":1,"result":{"currentBlock":"0xfe0600","healedBytecodeBytes":"0x7c6e7","healedBytecodes":"0x45","healedTrienodeBytes":"0x8737562","healedTrienodes":"0x9b921","healingBytecode":"0x0","healingTrienodes":"0x454","highestBlock":"0xfe0653","startingBlock":"0xfdfcf3","syncedAccountBytes":"0xb86436128","syncedAccounts":"0xc1e42e3","syncedBytecodeBytes":"0x14e2b1bbb","syncedBytecodes":"0xcb4a9","syncedStorage":"0x36583a3a","syncedStorageBytes":"0x2d9574d1e5"}} ``` #### snapshot Disk

@Tadouh Geth caches a lot of trie nodes in RAM, as in dirty trie nodes that were never written to disk. If you murder Geth, all that data is lost and it needs to rerun a lot of past blocks to recover it. That's not a resync, it jsut needs to go back in time to get the data. Doesn't matter what database you use, it has to do the same.

The point behind this operation is to limit the amount of data we write to disk. Rather we keep new things in RAM until they turn out to be "probably" necessary to write out.
If in your case Geth does indeed do a full resync, please provide some logs. I doubt it though.
We're slowly merging in a new trie data model though, that won't require in memory garbage collection and will forever solve this issue of losing trie nodes and having to go back in time.

Does it reduce latency, we deploy a lot of staking operations and often the balance is reduced due to slow synchronization @karalabe

Pebble and leveldb have the same design concept, both are based on LSM-Tree storage engine. However, go-leveldb is not actively maintained but pebble has a team behind it. It's expected that pebble will bring up more optimizations/features.

And also one obvious advantage pebble has is concurrent compaction. The efficiency of compaction is the bottleneck of storage engine write performance to some extent. However, we found that in the process of compaction, disk reading and writing only takes up a small part of the time, but most of the time is for CPU operations, such as SNAPPY encode/decode, CRC checksum, etc. So introducing concurrent compaction is a straightforward idea. Unfortunately go-leveldb author thought that this project won't accept major change such as concurrent compaction. Unlikely it's supported by pebble. It can be the reason for higher disk ops with pebble. (Note, SSD can offer with high disk ops, but leveldb can't use that capacity but pebble uses more).
